title: Welcome to the Community Beta
body:
Hey folks, 

For the last little while a small team of Rioters have been thinking about how League of Legends players interact online outside of the game itself. Players have conversations, they share awesome content, and they form communities.

A lot of that interaction happens back on our official forums. Traditional forums are pretty great at fostering discussion, but with a community as large and talkative as ours it can be truly overwhelming to find the content you want or the conversations you want to add your voice to. We’ve also heard a ton of feedback from you guys with ideas on how to improve the official forums.

So we took a step back and thought about how we could best serve the community’s needs. We looked at other thriving community and social platforms, we talked to players about what they want, we drank a lot of coffee, and we started building a new community platform with this goal in mind:

We want to create a player-driven platform that brings the community together around awesome content and discussions relevant to your interests.

* You should be able to find awesome content that you care about
* It should be easy to have great conversations with other players and Rioters
* Your actions should influence the community
* You should be able to form friendships and build communities with like-minded players
* Your feedback should shape the future of the platform

So we’ve been working on this for a little while now – but we can only get so far on our research and assumptions. We need you to participate – post, upvote, downvote, discuss, debate, and test what we built (read: break stuff).

What we really need the most is for you to tell us what you think so we can move forward and work with you to build something great for the community. We’re excited to share what we’ve got today, but it’s important for you to know that this is an early look – it’s gonna change and grow and evolve based on the community’s direction.

So, welcome – help us test this and make it better. Community pls!

Oh, and go here to ask us anything about the project: http://community.na.leagueoflegends.com/c/beta-feedback/f1Fsz53Q-were-the-team-behind-the-community-beta-ask-us-anything

**FAQ:**

**Will this replace the forums?**
Maybe one day. I can’t state this strongly enough, though: this is at a super early stage. We’re asking YOU to shape the direction of this platform to be the best possible place for League of Legends content and discussion.

**Is this available globally?**
For our first round of testing, to keep things focused, we’re just launching this for the NA region, but anyone with an NA account can participate. Based on community feedback, we’ll think about the right time to bring this to other regions and languages.

**Will posts from the current forums appear here?**
Nope. It’s a brand new platform and the way discussions work is fundamentally different so it’d be pretty messy to try to copy and paste things over.

**Can I give feedback?**
YES! GIVE FEEDBACK! Go here and tell us your thoughts: http://community.na.leagueoflegends.com/c/beta-feedback

**When will it be done?**
Short answer: never. Just like with League of Legends, we’re committed to constantly improving this based on your feedback.

**Is this inspired by Reddit?**
We took inspiration from a variety of community and social platforms that have been extremely successful at serving community needs. Reddit’s a big one, for sure, but we’re also looking at Facebook, Disqus, and a dozen other discussion and social sites. That got us to where we are today – now it’s your opportunity to help shape this.

**Why couldn’t you make improvements to the existing forums?**
The current forums use off-the-shelf forums software (vBulletin) that’s really great at what it does. However, the changes necessary to accomplish our goals would basically mean rewriting the whole platform anyway, so we decided to build something new ourselves.

**Where will you keep us up to date on changes?**
We’ll have constant update threads in the Beta Feedback subcommunity with the latest updates.

Oh, sorry, I thought you meant "formatting" as in BBCode versus Markdown, not multi-threaded comments versus single-threaded comments. I'm going to parse out a few of your pieces of feedback and respond to them. The formatting is absolute crap. Coming from someone who earns his living entirely off front-end web development, whoever came up with the idea that "space space enter" should mean line-break needs to feel a little bit bad about it.

Why is enter to break not good enough? Who is expected to understand space space enter by default? I've never seen that anywhere.

The short answer is that we're using a strict interpretation of the [Markdown spec](http://daringfireball.net/projects/markdown/syntax#p), which includes only respecting a line-break as a '
' when it's followed by two spaces. The longer answer is related to styling and readability. Here's Markdown's designer on paragraph versus line-break formatting: > A paragraph is simply one or more consecutive lines of text, separated by one or more blank lines. (A blank line is any line that looks like a blank line — a line containing nothing but spaces or tabs is considered blank.) Normal paragraphs should not be indented with spaces or tabs. > The implication of the “one or more consecutive lines of text” rule is that Markdown supports “hard-wrapped” text paragraphs. This differs significantly from most other text-to-HTML formatters (including Movable Type’s “Convert Line Breaks” option) which translate every line break character in a paragraph into a '
' tag. > When you do want to insert a '
' break tag using Markdown, you end a line with two or more spaces, then type return. > Yes, this takes a tad more effort to create a '
', but a simplistic “every line break is a '
'” rule wouldn’t work for Markdown. Markdown’s email-style blockquoting and multi-paragraph list items work best — and look better — when you format them with hard breaks. I feel there's also another, more important reason, to not respect a simple line-break as a '
', besides the flexibility to hard-wrap paragraphs or block-quotes. It forces the writer to write for the reader -- you have to decide why you're using single-line breaks and format appropriately. If you're creating a list, it makes more sense to use the list style (starting a line with a \- or \*). That way, we can tell what you're doing and style it in a way that's best for the reader -- might be mobile, might be desktop, might be a totally different visual style down the line. Sometimes writers will use single line-breaks *as* paragraph breaks, and these are virtually unreadable. In that case, it really does makes sense to use two. That's my thought. It's certainly not the end-all for Markdown -- services like GitHub respect line-breaks inline -- but I feel like there are some good reasons to stick to the strict Markdown spec, especially to make posts work primarily *for readers*. What do you think?

And there's so many other things I keep bumping in to.

3. To even get to my profile to see my posts, I had to scroll all the way up to the page (about 6 screen's worth of scrolling), and then all the way back down and figure out where my reply was. This problem doesn't exist in the standard threaded view, but the Reddit style will show hundreds of posts in a single view.

Hate to nit-pick you to death but I really love webdev and I see you guys are passionate about the new community area, so I'm trying to chip in as long as it's welcomed.

I really appreciate your feedback, and I *love* nitpicking. That's how you design something that's fun and intuitive to use.

> ( By the way, the list in that topic (copied over from YouTube) is a great example of painfully adding double spaces after every line, going to preview to make sure I didn't miss any, and then going back to add more if I did. It's really annoying. )

For a numbered list, you can just start a line with a number. It then becomes an ordered list. No forced formatting needed. It looks like you picked that up by the end of your comment.

I'll make sure MoltovCarrot sees your all your feedback here. I think you're onto something by separating comments with a little more space. May be something we'll experiment with.

One of the most sobering things with my job and talking to other developers is seeing how differently people place their values. Something I'd take for granted, like chronological threading or bbcode, is considered "baggage" to other people. There's a really indescribable feeling you get when you say something you think is universally true and are told, "nah, that's wrong."

As an experiment, I made three very small changes to the layout of the thread.

1. I added this rule to hide replies of replies: #discussion .primary-comments-container .primary-comments-container { display: none; }
2. Doubled the margin-top of the first replies.
3. Changed "Show More" to "Show All Replies"

And here's the result:
http://i.imgur.com/qlnCEER.png

I think this resolved a lot of my complaints. Posts are very easy to distinguish, irrelevant replies to replies to replies are hidden, and you can see the discussion of the original topic without distraction. But, the availability to see sub-discussions is still there.

What I think is very interesting about the layout I've given is it does exactly what the layout is supposed to. My comment about "unpopular opinions would get downvoted to oblivion" doesn't hold weight here. You see two conflicting opinions up at the very top, with more ideas of how to reach middle ground below it. If I wanted to see discussion about a particular idea, the availability of replying or showing all replies is there without being shoved into my face. Everything relevant is readily available, everything extraneous is easy to open but not in the way.
